name: carom
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
US (UK cannon) to hit something and bounce back, especially at an angle: She had her final shot carom off the back of the rim. Kids run wild and beach balls carom around the lobby.
US (UK cannon) to move or change in an uncontrolled way between different places, things, or subjects: We must not give the virus the chance to carom wildly through human hosts as it does in a flock of chickens or ducks. The book has 84 short chapters that carom from one issue to the next and fail to tackle anything in much depth.
More examplesFewer examplesIf you're not careful your ball will carom left off the severely sloped fairway into the rough.After losing one of its propellers, the plane caroms off a neighbour's palm tree.Vehicles striking the guardrails or sheer mountainsides can carom across the traffic lanes. The kids grab their food and carom away in different directions.Bounding about the stage, she caroms from girlish giddiness to boyish bluster and back again.The plot caroms between the self-consciously camp and the unapologetically bizarre.

carom noun
(IN GAMES)
[ C ] US (UK cannon) in billiards or pool, an occasion when the ball hits two other balls one after the other: A carom can be useful in pool and they’re deadly if used at the right time.
[ U ] US (also carom billiards) a game similar to billiards played on a table without pockets: The place is mainly a spot for people to play cards or three-ball pocketless carom billiards.
yongsuk son/iStock/Getty Images Plus/GettyImages
[ C ] US a rebound (= an occasion when something such as a ball bounces back after hitting a hard surface), especially at an angle: The ball took a carom, shooting back toward the right-field line.
More examplesFewer examplesSometimes two balls are extremely close to being at the correct angle for a carom but not quite.The truckers have a transport office where they relax and play carom, a sort of cross between draughts and billiards.Ronaldo took the carom and buried it in the net.

carom noun
(SEED)
[ C or U ] (also carom seed) a seed that is used as a spice, especially in South Asian cooking: The seeds are known as bishop's weed, ajwain and carom. Carom seeds, or ajwain as they are called in India, are somewhat similar to thyme in flavour, though more pungent. Synonym
ajwain
